title: 115_s425
content: The "Historic Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2017" may increase the rehabilitation credit for certain small projects. The "Historic Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2017" may increase the rehabilitation credit for small projects by substituting '30 percent' for '20 percent' in certain cases, with a maximum credit limit of $750,000. The term 'small project' refers to a certified historic structure with total qualified rehabilitation expenditures not exceeding $3,750,000 and no credit allowed in the two previous taxable years. The amendment applies after the enactment of the Act. The Act allows for tax credits for small projects on certified historic structures, with total qualified rehabilitation expenditures not exceeding $3,750,000. The credits apply after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. ALLOWANCE FOR THE TRANSFER OF CREDITS FOR CERTAIN SMALL PROJECTS. The taxpayer can transfer a portion of the credit for a small project to another taxpayer, with certification requirements. The taxpayer can transfer a portion of the credit for a small project to another taxpayer, with certification requirements including the transferee's information and project details. The credit can only be transferred once and no deduction is allowed for consideration paid for the transfer. The transferee can receive a credit under this section for the taxable year in which the credit is transferred, with recapture and special rules applying for smaller projects. The amendment made by this section applies to periods after December 31, 2016, regarding the transfer of credits between a transferor and transferee, with reporting requirements set by the Secretary. SEC. 4 amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the type of buildings eligible for rehabilitation by adjusting the basis. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2016. SEC. 5 reduces the basis adjustment for rehabilitation property. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust the rules for the rehabilitation credit, limiting the amount that can be taken into account. Additionally, there is a coordination with basis adjustment for property eligible for the credit. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code adjust the rules for the rehabilitation credit, limiting the amount that can be taken into account. The income of the lessee of the property will include 50 percent of the credit allowable under section 38, ratably over the shortest recovery period applicable to the property. These amendments apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. MODIFICATIONS REGARDING CERTAIN TAX-EXEMPT USE PROPERTY. Amends section 47(c)(2)(B)(v)(I) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Effective for property placed in service after the enactment of this Act.
